newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Sound of ancient chime will ring HK historic change.
newsitem.headline: Sound of ancient chime will ring HK historic change.

text.p: Sixty-five bronze bells will ring out an historic change here with chimes heard in China 2,400 years ago -- and the world will have a chance to buy the CD record.
Their unique sound, from gentle shimmer to solemn boom, will signal China's July 1 recovery of Hong Kong colony from Britain.
The bells, weighing a total of five tonnes, are an exact replica in appearance and tone of priceless musicaL relics recovered from a nobleman's tomb of the Warring States dynastic era.
They are part of a new symphony, with acclaimed cellist Yo Yo Ma as soloist, and a local children's choir, to mark the first day of Chinese rule.

Commissioned for the event, the work will be played for the first time during a multi-million dollar extravaganza of fireworks, lasers, an illuminated barge flotilla and giant balloons after the transfer of power.
Hong Kong, a British colony for 156 years, reverts to Chinese rule at midnight on June 30, just 34 days away.
The score, titled "Symphony 1997 -- Heaven, Earth, Mankind", is by Chinese composer Tan Dun, a New York resident.
"We want a symphony that can leave a memory to our future generations of the day of July 1," said a spokesman for a pro-China committee organising the handover ceremony.

Raymond Wu, of the Association for Celebration of Reunification of Hong Kong with China, told a news conference on Wednesday that he would like the symphony to be recognised by everyone around the world.
The last of three movements incorporates a "lullaby" theme in which a parent's song to a child symbolises China's love for Hong Kong which Britain seized from the old Manchu empire.

Sony Classical, a unit of Japan's Sony Corp, will release a recording worldwide on July 5, the same day the 55-minute work will be performed in Beijing, the record company general manager Sonya Ho-Asjoe said.
It will also be played in a concert in Hong Kong on July 4.
A replica of the bianzhang-chime bells, unearthed from an aristocrat's tomb in central China in 1978, will be flown in from China.
Wu said the original 65 bells, which require five people to play, were too precious to "move around and play around with".
Tan, 40, who was born in China, was the youngest composer ever to win the prestige Suntory Prize Commission in 1993, while Ma, 42, is a ten-time Grammy award winner.
